list.title: Question 1
list.content: What provides evidence that all life on Earth evolved from the same population of cells?A.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells.B.\hspace{1em}Both mitochondria and prokaryotes have a cell wall.C.\hspace{1em}Both eukaryotes and bacteria contain histones.D.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is universal.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All 64 codons of the genetic code are present in all organisms, apart from minor variations indicating that all life evolved from the same original cells  (Choice D).Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells (Choice A) is incorrect as this is the endosymbiotic theory.Choice Bis incorrect as mitochondria do not have a cell wall.Choice Cis incorrect as bacteria do not have histones.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
What is the main role of the ribosomes labelled in the micrograph?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/27f4e9b2-a827-45ea-adaa-3d1c5221f126/images/9ecd433c-f10b-472c-93ea-f2ada27190ee/rough%20endoplasmic%20reticulum%20RER%20rough%20ER.png)

[Adapted from OpenStax. (2016, May 18).File:0313 endoplasmic reticulum B en.png- Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 1, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:0313_Endoplasmic_Reticulum_b_en.png. Copyright free]A.\hspace{1em}Synthesise enzymes to be used within the cytoplasmB.\hspace{1em}Transport mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasmC.\hspace{1em}Destroy proteins that the cell no longer needsD.\hspace{1em}Synthesise proteins for use in lysosomes
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Bound ribosomes synthesise proteins for secretion outside of the cell, membrane-associated proteins or proteins used in lysosomes (Choice D).While ribosomes do synthesize enzymes, the ribosomes attached to the rough ER specifically target the proteins they synthesize for secretion or for use in membrane-bound organelles (like lysosomes) or the cell membrane, rather than for immediate use within the cytoplasm. Proteins meant to function within the cytoplasm are typically synthesized by free ribosomes that are not attached to the rough ER.Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Bis incorrect as bound ribosomes do not transport mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.Choice Cis incorrect as ribosomes do not destroy proteins.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: A strand of nucleotides reads CCUAGAGCUUACCG. Which type of pentose sugar could be found in the nucleotides in the natural composition of this strand?A.\hspace{1em}Deoxyribose onlyB.\hspace{1em}Ribose onlyC.\hspace{1em}Both deoxyribose and riboseD.\hspace{1em}Neither deoxyribose nor ribose
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The nucleotide strand CCUAGAGCUUACCG contains the bases cytosine (C), uracil (U), adenine (A), and guanine (G). While C, A, and G are found in both DNA and RNA, the base uracil is only found in RNA. So, the strand is an RNA strand.RNA contains the pentose sugar ribose. Therefore, ribose is found in the nucleotides in the strand.Choices AandCare incorrect because deoxyribose is only found in DNA, not RNA. The nucleotide strand cannot be DNA because it contains uracil in place of thymine (T).Choice Dis incorrect because the strand is RNA which contains ribose.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which statement is correct concerning the structure of DNA?A.\hspace{1em}A phosphate within a nucleotide is covalently bonded to a nitrogenous baseB.\hspace{1em}DNA molecules are made up of two parallel strands running in the same 3'-5' direction, linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary basesC.\hspace{1em}Bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNAD.\hspace{1em}Adenine is complementary to uracil, and cytosine is complementary to guanine
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Covalent bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNA;Choice Cis correct.Within nucleotides, the phosphate is covalently bonded to the deoxyribose sugar and the sugar is attached to the base;Choice Ais incorrect. DNA molecules are made up of two antiparallel strands (they are parallel but run in opposite directions, one runs 3’-5’ and the other 5’-3’), linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases;Choice Bis incorrect. In DNA, adenine is complementary to thymine;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: What distinguishes uracil from thymine?UracilThymineA.\hspace{1em}Joined to a pentose sugarJoined to a hexose sugarB.\hspace{1em}Found in RNAFound in DNAC.\hspace{1em}Two-ring structureSingle-ring structureD.\hspace{1em}Complementary to cytosineComplementary to adenine
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Uracil and thymine are nitrogenous bases found in two types of nucleic acids: DNA and RNA.Uracil is found in RNA, whereas thymine is found in DNA. (Choice B)In RNA, Uracil is not complementary to cystine, it is complementary with adenine, and thymine is also complementary to adenine
(Choice D).In both DNA and RNA, these nitrogenous bases are joined to a five-carbon sugar, also called a pentose sugar which has a ring structure, soChoice Ais incorrect.Both uracil and thymine are pyrimidines which are single-ring structures (Choice C). Adenine and guanine are purines which consist of two rings.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which statements are characteristics of a DNA molecule?I.The two strands are identical.II.The two strands are antiparallel to one another.III.The sugar-phosphate backbone is held together by covalent bonds.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A DNA molecule is made up of two antiparallel strands of nucleotides. Antiparallel means that both strands are geometrically parallel but oriented in opposite directions (Option II). One of the strands is in the direction of 5' to 3', whereas the other strand is in the direction of 3' to 5'. The backbones, made of alternating sugar and phosphate groups, are held together by covalent sugar-phosphate bonds (Option III). Both of these strands are joined together by the hydrogen bonds between the complementary base pairs.DNA strands are not identical (Option I) because identical would mean that they have the same nucleotide arrangement, instead they are complementary to each other.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Which of the following processes is most directly involved in the formation of nucleic acids such as DNA?A.\hspace{1em}HydrolysisB.\hspace{1em}CondensationC.\hspace{1em}CatabolismD.\hspace{1em}Translation
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Nucleotides are linked together by condensation reactions to form molecules of DNA (Choice B). The formation of DNA requires the removal of water for the joining of smaller molecules to form a larger molecule.The joining of nucleotides together can also be classified as an anabolic reaction but not as a catabolic reaction (Choice C). Catabolism is the breaking down of a large molecule into a smaller molecule. An example of catabolism is hydrolysis which is a reaction that breaks down a large molecule into a smaller molecule by adding water (Choice A).Translation is a process which follows the transcription of DNA (Choice D). It is where mRNA is used as a template by ribosomes to synthesize polypeptides.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which of the following best supports the idea that DNA is the universal genetic material in living organisms?A.\hspace{1em}All organisms have the same number of chromosomesB.\hspace{1em}All organisms translate proteins using ribosomesC.\hspace{1em}All organisms use DNA to pass on genetic informationD.\hspace{1em}All organisms reproduce sexually
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the use of DNA is universal across all living organisms.Choice Ais incorrect because chromosome number varies widely across different species.Choice Bis true, but it is not a statement specific to DNA being the genetic material.Choice Dis incorrect because not all organisms reproduce sexually.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: How does the genetic code provide evidence of universal common ancestry?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code of mitochondria is identical to the genetic code of the nucleus in eukaryotes.B.\hspace{1em}Each amino acid is coded for by only one codon.C.\hspace{1em}Mutations cannot cause changes in the sequence of bases in the genome.D.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is the same across all three domains of life, with just a few exceptions.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The genetic code is largely the same in all known organisms. There are a few exceptions such as mitochondrial DNA which can vary slightly in codon assignments for specific amino acids, and some bacterial species. ThereforeChoice Dis correct .Choice Ais incorrect because the genetic code used in mitochondria is similar to the genetic code used in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells but not entirely the same.Choice Bis incorrect because the genetic code is degenerate. There are 64 possible codons in the genetic code, but only 20 amino acids. As a result, some amino acids are coded for by more than one codon, providing redundancy and flexibility in protein synthesis.Choice Cis incorrect because mutations are changes in the genetic code. As a result, mutations play a significant role in generating genetic diversity and are a driving force in the process of evolution.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Which statement explains why DNA is evidence of common ancestry?A.\hspace{1em}All organisms have an identical DNA base sequence.B.\hspace{1em}All organisms contain DNA.C.\hspace{1em}Closely related species contain the same alleles.D.\hspace{1em}More recently evolved species have more similar DNA.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because the presence of DNA in all organisms reflects a universal lineage, providing evidence of common ancestry. All organisms use the same four nucleotides (adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine) and the same genetic code to translate DNA into proteins, which supports the idea of a shared evolutionary origin.Choice Ais incorrect because while all organisms share common sequences in their DNA, their base sequences are not identical. Differences in DNA sequences accumulate over time, and species with more recent common ancestors have more similar DNA.Choice Cis incorrect because organisms that are closely related share many similarities in their DNA but their alleles are not all identical.Choice Dis incorrect because all organisms, living and extinct, contain DNA, not only recently evolved species.

list.content: Which set of bonds found in nucleic acids are correctly identified in the table below?Bonds between phosphates and pentose sugarsBonds between nucleotide basesA.\hspace{1em}CovalentHydrogenB.\hspace{1em}HydrogenCovalentC.\hspace{1em}CovalentCovalentD.\hspace{1em}HydrogenHydrogen
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the nucleic acid backbone is held together by covalently bonded sugars and phosphates, while the nucleotide bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.Choice Bis incorrect because the types of bonds are reversed.Choice Cis incorrect because the bonds between nucleotides are hydrogen bonds, not covalent bonds.Choice Dis incorrect because the bonds between phosphates and pentose sugars are covalent, not hydrogen bonds.

list.content:

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Which of the following molecules are classified as nucleic acids?I.ATPII.rRNAIII.DNAA.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}I and IIIC.\hspace{1em}II and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis false. ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is a nucleotide, not a nucleic acid. It is a single molecule, not a long chain (polymer) of nucleotides, which is what defines nucleic acids like DNA and RNA.Statement IIis true. Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) is a type of RNA, which is one of the two major types of nucleic acids (the other being DNA). It is a polymer of ribonucleotides, synthesised during transcription, and plays a role in protein synthesis.Statement IIIis true. DNA is a polymer of deoxyribonucleotides. It serves as the hereditary material in most organisms.Note that the correct answer includes the two molecules whose names end in ‘NA’, which stands for nucleic acid - DNA and RNA.Choice Cis, therefore, the correct answer as it only includes the two trueStatements IIandIII.Choices A, BandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement I.

list.title: Question 16
list.markScheme: BSample answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}Sample answer​:RNA is a single strand of nucleotides (Uracil, Guanine, Adenine and Cytosine), bonded together by a phosphodiester backbone. Each nucleotide consists of a phosphate group (represented by a circle), joined to a ribose sugar (represented by a pentagon) joined to a base (represented by a rectangle). Each nucleotide is joined to another by a covalent bond between the  ribose sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate of the next.Choice Bis correct.Choice Ais incorrect as RNA is single stranded, not double stranded.Choice Cis incorrect as it shows a hexose sugar rather than a pentose sugar.Choice Dis incorrect as the pentose sugars and phosphate groups are in the wrong positions.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: What characteristic of DNA allows it to serve as a template for both DNA replication and mRNA synthesis?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code in DNA is universal across all organismsB.\hspace{1em}Hydrogen bonding enables the correct alignment of deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides in newly synthesised strandsC.\hspace{1em}DNA’s double helix structure means one strand can be replicated at the same time as the other is being transcribedD.\hspace{1em}The strong sugar-phosphate backbone
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct. During both replication and transcription, nucleotides are aligned along the DNA template strand according to base-pairing rules. Hydrogen bonds form between the nitrogenous bases of the template DNA strand and the incoming deoxyribonucleotides (during replication) or ribonucleotides (in transcription).The genetic code being universal means that the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms. However, this relates to protein synthesis, not to how DNA acts as a template for replication or transcription;Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect because replication and transcription can’t occur on opposite strands simultaneously.Choice Dis incorrect because while the sugar-phosphate backbone is a feature of both DNA and RNA strands that provides structural stability, it does not explain how DNA can interact with both DNA and RNA nucleotides.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: Which of the following is the correct pairing of a nucleotide component and its description?ComponentDescriptionA.\hspace{1em}SugarVaries between RNA and DNA to form genetic codeB.\hspace{1em}BaseProvides structure to the backboneC.\hspace{1em}PhosphateForms bonds with the base and sugarD.\hspace{1em}BaseVaries along nucleic acid to form genetic code
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Dis correct because the sequence of nitrogenous bases is what encodes genetic information in DNA and RNA. This is the only row with a fully correct and precise description.Choice Ais incorrect because, while the sugar differs between DNA (deoxyribose) and RNA (ribose), it does not form the genetic code. The code is carried in the base sequence, not the sugar.Choice Bis incorrect because Bases are not part of the backbone (which is made of sugar–phosphate units). Bases project from the backbone and form the coding region, not the structure.Choice Cis incorrect because phosphate forms bonds with sugars, not with bases. Bases attach to the sugar (at carbon 1'), not to phosphate.

list.title: Question 23
list.content: Which of the following features of DNA most directly underpins its virtually limitless capacity to encode genetic information?A.\hspace{1em}The use of four chemically distinct nitrogenous bases arranged in long chains.B.\hspace{1em}Semiconservative replication via complementary base pairing, which preserves sequence diversity.C.\hspace{1em}The covalent sugar-phosphate backbone’s antiparallel orientation, which fixes strand directionality.D.\hspace{1em}Coiling of DNA into chromosomes, which aids efficient storage.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because the linear sequence of four different nucleotides (A, T, C and G) joined by phosphodiester bonds can form an almost infinite number of unique combinations, providing DNA with its enormous information-storage capacity. The human genome is about 3,000,000,000 nucleotides long, so there would be**43,000,000,000\mathbf{4^{3,000,000,000}}43,000,000,000theoretical combinations of nucleotides.Choice Bis incorrect because complementary base pairing ensures faithful replication, but does not itself generate new sequences.Choice Cis incorrect because the antiparallel backbone ensures the strands are arranged in opposite directions, but does not contribute to the sequence diversity.Choice Dis incorrect because coiling allows DNA to be compacted and stored efficiently within the nucleus, but it does not directly contribute to thecapacityto encode genetic information. While necessary for packaging long DNA molecules, coiling does not influence the number of unique sequences that DNA can carry or its ability to store diverse instructions.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
What bases are P, Q, and R if S is a pyrimidine?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f497fb1a-2df4-4043-a760-f2d78e9bc76a/images/3b6c2a4e-8c5c-4c00-a882-93d69b4c4568/BI0897A.png)

[© Revision Village 2023]PQRA.\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Guanine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Cytosine\hspace{1em}\hspace{1em}Thymine\hspace{1em}B.\hspace{1em}GuanineAdenineCytosineC.\hspace{1em}CytosineGuanineAdenineD.\hspace{1em}AdenineThymineCytosine
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Adenine and guanine are purines. Cytosine and thymine are pyrimidines.If S is a pyrimidine (~20%), it is either cytosine or thymine. Purines pair with pyrimidines, so Q, which also makes up about 20% of the molecule, must be guanine or adenine. This meansChoices AandDcan be eliminated as correct answers.P and R must pair up as they make up approximately the same proportion of the DNA. So P and R must either be adenine and thymine or guanine and cytosine. This meansChoice Cis incorrect.This leaves us with the correct answer ofChoice B.  P is guanine, which pairs with R, cytosine, and Q is adenine, which pairs with S, which must be thymine.
